task.title: Install Plant Applications Universal Client Docker on Windows

taskbody.prereq:
Before you begin the installation of the Plant Applications Universal Client Docker on the Windows system, ensure that:
You are an Administrator with execute permissions.
You have either Windows 10 or Windows 2016 server available to run the exe file.
Your system meets the preinstallation requirements.
You have the following UAA and CouchDB certificates in your system.
uaa_server.crt
uaa_server.pem
uaa_server.key
couch_cert_crt.crt

step.cmd: Download the software and extract the files to the machine where you want to install Plant Applications Universal Client Docker and then run the Plant Application Docker 8.0.exe file as an Administrator.
step.stepresult: The Plant Applications Docker wizard appears, displaying the Welcome to Plant Applications Docker 8.0 screen.

step.cmd: In the Welcome to Plant Applications Docker 8.0 screen, select Next.
step.stepresult: A screen appears, displaying the details of the Trusted Root Certificate validation. The Plant Applications Universal Client Docker supports the self-signed certificates as Trusted Root Certificates.

step.cmd: Select the Check here to proceed, but the install may fail check box, and then select Next.
Read the license agreement and select the I agree the terms in the license agreement check box, and then select Next to continue the installation.
step.stepresult: The Install Directory and DTR screen appears.

step.cmd: In the Installation Directory box, select the location where you want to install the Plant Applications Universal Client Docker and enter the credentials to access the Docker Trusted Registry (DTR).

ul.li:
For an Existing DTR user, enter your docker credentials as described in the following table.
CredentialDescription
Host NameEnter the hostname where the Docker server is installed in the format HOST_NAME\PORT_NUMBER, where HOST_NAME is either a fully qualified domain name or IP address of the server, and PORT_NUMBER is the port number of the server. You can use the hostname to access DTR web user interface to remotely connect with the DTR API, push and pull images, and access the applications hosted on the DTR cluster.

For a New DTR account, by default, the Hostname appears.Select the New DTR option if you do not have an account for the Docker Trusted Registry. This will create an account for you and the Hostname appears in the wizard.

info.note: If the credentials are successfully validated, the Next button is enabled.

step.cmd: Select Validate to validate the DTR credentials, and then select Next.
step.stepresult: The PA Database Credentials screen appears.

step.cmd: Enter the Plant Applications database and Apache Couch database credentials to establish connections with the databases.

ol.li:
In the Plant Applications DB tab, enter the Plant Applications database settings necessary to run the service specific scripts as described in the following table.The MS OLE DB tool is installed with this installer package to run these scripts.
CredentialDescription
Server NameEnter the IP address of the SOA database.
DatabaseEnter the name of the SOA database that you want to connect with the Plant Applications Universal Client.
InstanceEnter the instance name of the SQL server. Entering an instance is optional.
Note: You can specify values either for Instance or Port.
PortEnter the port number that the instance uses to listen for the client connections.
UsernameEnter the user name of the administrator who has read-write permissions to access the database you entered in the Database box. By default, the user name appears as sa.
PasswordEnter the password for the Administrator user you entered in the Username box.

In the CouchDB tab, enter your CouchDB credentials as described in the following table.
CredentialDescription
CouchDB Server UriEnter the fully qualified web address of the CouchDB in the format HTTP://PORT_NUMBER/INSTANCE_NAME.
DatabaseEnter the name of the CouchDB database that you want to connect with the Plant Applications Universal Client.
NodeEnter the name of the node where the CouchDB is running. This is an optional field and by default, the node value appears.
UsernameEnter the user name of the Administrator that has read-write permissions to access the database you entered in the Database box.
PasswordEnter the password for the user you entered in the Username box.
Select Import Certificates to import the CouchDB server certificate (couch_cert_crt.crt) to the Secrets folder.

step.cmd: Select Validate to validate the Plant Applications database and Apache Couch database credentials, and then select Next.
Enter the credentials of your RabbitMQ Administrator account for queuing the messages as described in the following table.

row.entry: Enter the IP address of the RabbitMQ server.
Enter the username of the Administrator who has read-write permissions to access the RabbitMQ server.
Enter the password for the user you entered in the Username box.

step.cmd: Select Validate to validate the RabbitMQ Administrator account credentials, and then select Next.
Enter the Cloud Foundry User Account and Authentication Service (UAA) details for authenticating the users to access the Plant Application Universal Client as described in the following table.

row.entry: Enter the fully qualified IP address of the CloudFoundry UAA server.
Enter the unique identifier used for authenticating the OAuth client in the UAA server.
Enter the unique password of the OAuth client.
Enter the Administrator user name who has permissions to access the UAA server.
Enter the unique password to authenticate and obtain an access token for the Administrator user from the UAA server.

step.cmd: Select Import Certificates to import the UAA server certificates (uaa_server.crt, uaa_server.pem, and uaa_server.key) to the Secrets folder and select Validate to validate the UAA credentials, and then select Next.
step.stepresult: The Plant Applications Docker screen appears, displaying all the exposed Plant Applications services that you can access through Swagger. You can also modify the port numbers.

step.cmd: Select Validate to validate the ports, and then select Next.
step.stepresult: The Universal Client screen appears, displaying the host name and port number that enables you to access all the Plant Applications Universal Client applications in the port.
The You are ready to install screen appears.

step.cmd: Select Install to install Plant Applications Universal Client Docker on Windows.

info.note: Depending on the options selected, the installation process may take some time. The installer displays the status updates.

taskbody.result: The Plant Applications Universal Client Docker application is installed successfully on Windows.
